The friend explicitly doesn't want to disclose her cancer diagnosis to avoid 'taking attention away from the happy couple.' The OP is respecting the friend's autonomy and wishes while using their skills to provide a practical, discreet solution. There is no malicious intent or desire to deceive - only to help.

This is a clear case of prioritizing human dignity and medical privacy over minor aesthetic concerns. The OP is acting with compassion to help a cancer patient maintain her privacy and comfort. The potential upset to the bride over dress modification pales in comparison to the friend's need for support during cancer treatment. The modifications would be subtle and maintain the dress's style. The greater good is served by helping the friend participate without unwanted disclosure.

results.title: AITA because I pushed my friend into making decisions?

assessment_steps.analysis: Multiple parties were harmed. Friend 3 experienced financial losses, physical injury (broken pelvis), and ongoing stress from OP's persistent pushing. OP's recommendations led to maintenance issues with cars and bikes, a missed house opportunity, and job dissatisfaction. OP also suffered harm - lost friendships, social isolation for 9 months, and damaged relationships with the entire friend group. Friends 1 and 2 were put in an uncomfortable position having to choose sides. The harm is moderate to significant, particularly the broken pelvis injury and complete breakdown of the friendship group.

OP appears to have had genuinely good intentions - wanting to help friends and sharing opportunities that worked well for them. They acknowledge having ADHD and impulsive tendencies, and state they've been 'REALLY working on this for the past two years.' However, OP admits to being 'reckless and annoying' and having a tendency to 'pester people.' The pattern shows poor execution of good intentions - being overly pushy and not respecting boundaries, despite claiming self-awareness and improvement efforts.

While OP had good intentions, their persistent pushing and inability to respect Friend 3's autonomy caused significant harm. OP admits to pestering behavior and being 'reckless and annoying.' The final phone contract issue was the breaking point after a pattern of unwanted interference. However, Friend 3 also bears some responsibility for not maintaining items and for completely cutting off the friendship over a relatively minor issue. The other friends' withdrawal suggests OP's behavior was problematic enough to damage multiple relationships. OP is primarily at fault for boundary violations despite good intentions.

OP appears to have mixed intentions - partly genuine desire to help friends but also admits to having a compulsive tendency to 'pester' people and get 'overly excited' about pushing decisions. OP acknowledges being 'wreckless and annoying' and admits that when friends express being overwhelmed, 'that's bait to me.' While there may be some good faith desire to help, the behavior shows poor boundaries and a pattern of imposing their will on others despite claiming to work on it for two years.

Significant harm occurred: Friend 3 ended the friendship entirely and explicitly blamed OP for multiple negative outcomes (car problems, missed house opportunity, bike issues, job dissatisfaction, injury from following OP snowboarding). The friend group has fractured, with friends 1 and 2 distancing themselves and excluding OP from gatherings. OP admits to being 'pretty alone' for 9 months. The pattern shows OP's pushy behavior created stress, financial consequences, and ultimately destroyed relationships despite OP's self-described good intentions.

While OP may have had some good intentions, their acknowledged pattern of pestering, pushing decisions on others, and inability to respect boundaries despite claiming to work on it resulted in serious relationship damage. OP admits to being 'wreckless and annoying' and sees others' distress as 'bait.' The harm to friend 3 and the entire friend group outweighs any helpful intentions, especially given OP's self-awareness of the problematic behavior.

results.title: AITA for buying ice cream?

assessment_steps.analysis: OP appears to be acting in good faith throughout. They followed their mother's explicit suggestion to buy ice cream on Friday instead of Saturday, confirmed the plan multiple times, and helped clean groceries when they returned. OP also informed their mother about the forgotten shoe because she had specifically requested to be told about such things. OP's intentions seem genuine - maintaining family traditions, following parental guidance, and being helpful around the house.

The harm here is minimal and largely stems from a miscommunication. The mother felt burdened by cleaning groceries alone temporarily, but OP did help upon returning and this was according to her own suggested plan. The mother's passive-aggressive response and subsequent cold treatment (including apparent indifference when OP passed out) seems disproportionate to any perceived slight. The mother's reaction appears to be causing more emotional harm to OP than any inconvenience OP caused her.

OP followed their mother's explicit suggestion, confirmed it multiple times, helped with cleaning when they returned, and was following established household communication norms about the shoe. The mother's passive-aggressive response and cold treatment seems unreasonable given that OP was following her own plan. While there may have been a miscommunication about timing, OP acted reasonably and in good faith throughout.

The harm in this scenario is relatively minor but notable. The mother felt burdened by having to clean groceries alone while OP went to buy ice cream, leading to resentment and tension in the household. The mother's subsequent cold treatment of OP (not noticing/responding when OP passed out) represents emotional harm and withdrawal of care. OP experienced confusion, guilt, and physical distress without maternal support. The harm is primarily emotional/relational rather than severe material damage.

OP's intentions appear to be good faith throughout. They followed their mother's explicit suggestion to buy ice cream on Friday instead of Saturday, confirmed the plan multiple times, and helped clean groceries upon return. OP informed mother about the forgotten shoe because mother had previously requested such reminders. OP seems genuinely confused about why mother is upset since they followed her suggested plan. The mother's intent is less clear - she may have expected OP to prioritize cleaning over ice cream buying, but she explicitly suggested the Friday plan herself.

Based on the harm and intent analysis, OP followed their mother's explicit instructions in good faith and helped with cleaning when they returned. The mother suggested the Friday plan but then became resentful when OP followed it. While there may have been a miscommunication about priorities, OP cannot be blamed for following their mother's own suggestion. The mother's subsequent cold treatment seems disproportionate to any perceived slight. OP is not at fault here.

results.title: AITA for feeling threatened by my partner’s bi-sexual friend

assessment_steps.analysis: Currently, no concrete harm has occurred. The OP has observed behaviors that make them uncomfortable but has not acted on these feelings or brought them up with anyone. No relationships have been damaged, no trust has been broken, and no confrontations have happened. The potential for harm exists if the situation is handled poorly, but actual harm is minimal at this stage.

The OP appears to be acting in good faith, seeking advice before taking action and expressing concern about not wanting to seem 'crazy or insecure.' They acknowledge their partner's openness about sexuality and seem supportive of that. However, their discomfort seems based largely on assumptions and interpretations of body language rather than concrete evidence of inappropriate behavior. The intent is to address legitimate relationship concerns, but the approach may be influenced by insecurity.

The OP is not an asshole for having feelings of discomfort, as emotions are natural responses. However, they would become problematic if they acted on these feelings without clear evidence or communication. Since they're seeking advice on how to handle this appropriately and haven't actually done anything harmful yet, they're not in the wrong. The situation involves natural relationship insecurities that need healthy communication rather than judgment.

OP's intentions appear to be genuinely concerned about his relationship and seeking advice on how to address his discomfort appropriately. He explicitly states he doesn't want to 'come across as crazy or insecure' and asks for advice on how to bring this up 'without looking like an asshole.' He hasn't acted on these feelings yet and is seeking guidance before potentially causing harm. His motivation seems to be preserving his relationship while addressing legitimate concerns about boundaries.

Currently, no actual harm has occurred since OP hasn't brought this up with anyone yet. The observations he describes (cuddling, close body language, eye contact) could be interpreted as normal close friendship behavior, especially between two people who share mental health struggles. However, his discomfort is valid, and if left unaddressed, could lead to resentment or relationship damage. The potential harm would come from either suppressing valid concerns or from approaching the situation poorly and damaging trust with his partner.

OP is not an asshole for having these feelings or concerns. Relationships involve boundaries and communication, and feeling uncomfortable about certain behaviors is natural. The key is that he recognizes he needs to handle this sensitively and is seeking advice rather than making accusations or demands. His approach of wanting to communicate openly with his partner while being mindful of not appearing controlling shows emotional maturity.

results.title: AITA for not washing dishes?

assessment_steps.analysis: The harm here is relatively minor but multifaceted. The mother was verbally abused with profanity, which causes emotional harm and disrespects the parent-child relationship. The household conflict creates tension and stress for all family members. The mother's transportation threat causes inconvenience to OP (45-60 minutes daily), while OP's defiance undermines parental authority. The utility cost concern from the mother, while minimal in absolute terms, represents a legitimate household management issue. Overall harm is moderate - primarily emotional/relational rather than severe material damage.

OP's intent appears mixed - they genuinely want to use an appliance they purchased for its intended purpose of convenience and time-saving, which is reasonable. However, their response escalated unnecessarily with profanity directed at their mother. The mother's intent seems to be household resource management and maintaining parental authority, though her approach of restricting dishwasher use to twice yearly is extreme and undermines the appliance's purpose. Both parties acted with some legitimate motivations but poor execution - OP wanted reasonable appliance use, mother wanted resource conservation, but both handled the conflict poorly.

While OP had legitimate reasons for wanting to use the dishwasher they purchased, telling their mother 'fuck you' was a disproportionate and disrespectful response that crosses a clear line. The mother's position on dishwasher usage was unreasonable, but OP's verbal abuse was the more serious offense in this conflict. The harm from the profanity and disrespect outweighs the reasonableness of OP's underlying position about appliance usage.

OP's primary intent appears to be using a dishwasher they purchased for its intended purpose - convenience and time-saving. They wanted to be productive and efficient with their time. However, their response escalated unnecessarily when they told their mother 'fuck you' rather than attempting constructive dialogue about the utility cost concerns or finding a compromise.

The harm includes: OP caused emotional hurt to their mother by using profanity and being disrespectful. The mother's threat to withdraw transportation support created inconvenience for OP. The conflict damaged the parent-child relationship and created household tension. While OP's desire to use their purchased appliance is reasonable, their disrespectful communication caused significant relational harm.

While OP had legitimate reasons for wanting to use the dishwasher they purchased, their response was disproportionately disrespectful. Telling a parent 'fuck you' over a household chore disagreement crosses clear boundaries of respect, regardless of the underlying issue's validity. The mother's concerns about utility costs, while perhaps excessive, don't justify such disrespectful language.

results.title: AITA for not going to my gf place?

assessment_steps.analysis: OP's intention appears to be acting out of genuine practical concern and discomfort about staying overnight without basic utilities like working toilets and water. They expressed worry about being a burden and feeling uncomfortable as a guest in those conditions. There's no indication of bad faith - they offered to reschedule for the next day when utilities would be restored and acknowledged they rarely get to see each other.

The harm is relatively minor but real - the girlfriend is disappointed that their planned overnight visit was cancelled last minute, especially given they rarely see each other and OP had made a promise. She may feel rejected or that OP doesn't prioritize their relationship enough to endure temporary inconvenience. However, OP offered an immediate alternative (reschedule for tomorrow) to minimize the harm.

Given that OP acted with reasonable practical concerns, offered an immediate alternative solution, and showed consideration for both parties' comfort, while the harm was disappointment rather than anything severe or lasting, OP is not the asshole. The concerns about basic utilities were legitimate and the compromise offered was reasonable.

The primary harm is emotional disappointment to the girlfriend who was expecting her partner to visit as promised. She likely feels let down and possibly rejected, especially given they 'barely get to see each other.' The harm is relatively minor - it's temporary disappointment that can be resolved by rescheduling. No significant physical, financial, or long-term emotional damage occurred.

OP's intentions appear to be reasonable and considerate. They expressed legitimate practical concerns about staying overnight without working plumbing (no toilet, shower, or sink), particularly as a guest who doesn't want to be a burden to the household. They offered to reschedule for the next day when utilities would be restored, showing they still want to spend time together. This suggests good faith effort to balance comfort/practicality with relationship needs.

While the girlfriend's disappointment is understandable, OP's concerns about staying overnight without basic utilities are reasonable and practical. Not having access to a working toilet, shower, or sink creates legitimate discomfort and inconvenience, especially as an overnight guest. OP offered a reasonable alternative (rescheduling) and their decision was based on practical considerations rather than rejection of their partner. The harm caused is minimal and temporary.

results.title: AITA for asking my colleagues to help me clean?

assessment_steps.analysis: The OP's intent appears to be seeking fair contribution to shared cleaning duties. They were frustrated by what they perceived as colleagues deliberately working slowly to avoid cleaning responsibilities, forcing OP to do more work. The OP's request for help with specific tasks and their upset tone seem motivated by a desire for equitable workload distribution rather than malicious intent. However, their anger and frustration may have influenced how they communicated.

The harm appears minimal. The colleague may have felt embarrassed or uncomfortable when OP corrected them in an upset tone, and the sous-chef noticed tension requiring intervention. The OP left 17 minutes early, suggesting the situation was disruptive to workplace harmony. However, no serious emotional damage, professional consequences, or lasting harm occurred. The colleague wasn't insulted or publicly humiliated, just directed somewhat tersely about cleaning tasks.

While OP's frustration about unequal work distribution is understandable, their method of expressing it created workplace tension. The colleague may have been genuinely trying to help by re-cleaning areas, and OP's upset tone was unprofessional even if not abusive. However, the core issue of unfair work distribution is legitimate, and OP didn't cross major ethical boundaries. This appears to be a workplace disagreement where OP could have handled their frustration better, but their underlying concern was valid.

The harm here is relatively minor. The colleague may have felt uncomfortable or criticized when OP expressed frustration about cleaning tasks. The workplace atmosphere became tense, and the sous-chef had to intervene. However, no serious emotional, physical, or professional damage occurred. OP was allowed to leave early, suggesting the situation was manageable and didn't escalate to serious consequences.

OP's intent appears to be seeking fair distribution of cleaning responsibilities rather than malicious. They express frustration about consistently doing more cleaning work while colleagues avoid contributing equally. OP didn't intend to harm or insult the colleague, but rather wanted appropriate help with shared duties. The frustration seems to stem from perceived unfairness and lack of teamwork, not from wanting to hurt anyone.

Given the minimal harm (temporary discomfort/tension) and OP's reasonable intent (seeking fair work distribution), OP is not the asshole. Workplace cleaning is a shared responsibility, and asking for help with clearly defined tasks is appropriate. While OP could have managed their frustration better, their core request was reasonable and their intent was not malicious.

results.title: AITA for badmouthing my best friend after she bailed on me b

assessment_steps.analysis: The primary harm was emotional - OP experienced disappointment and hurt after his friend canceled their Valentine's Day plans to get back with her boyfriend. OP also lost money on flowers and candy. However, the harm escalated when OP 'badmouthed' his friend in a group chat, calling her a 'shitty person' and getting others to turn against her. This created social consequences for the friend, potentially damaging her reputation and relationships within the friend group. The friend's Instagram post suggests she felt attacked by the group's reaction.

OP's initial intent was genuinely good - he wanted to help his depressed friend have a better Valentine's Day and put thought and money into planning something special. However, when hurt by her cancellation, OP's response was emotionally driven rather than constructive. He vented to the group chat seeking validation rather than trying to understand his friend's perspective or communicate directly with her. The friend's intent in canceling seems focused on her romantic relationship, and while inconsiderate, doesn't appear malicious.

While OP's disappointment was understandable and his friend's cancellation was inconsiderate, OP crossed a line by rallying the friend group against her instead of handling the conflict directly. The friend made a poor choice in how she handled the cancellation, but OP's response of publicly badmouthing her and turning their mutual friends against her was disproportionate to the harm he suffered. Both parties acted poorly, but OP's response caused more significant social harm.

OP's initial intent was genuinely good - wanting to help a depressed friend not spend Valentine's Day alone after a breakup. The plan to surprise her with flowers and candy shows thoughtful preparation. However, when she got back with her boyfriend and cancelled, OP's intent shifted to vindictive badmouthing in the group chat, calling her a 'shitty person' and rallying others against her. While disappointment is understandable, the response was retaliatory rather than constructive.

The friend's cancellation caused emotional harm to OP, who had invested time, money, and emotional energy into the plans. OP felt rejected and experienced depression. However, OP's badmouthing caused potentially greater harm - damaging the friend's reputation within their social circle, creating group animosity against her, and likely contributing to her feeling isolated (evidenced by her defensive Instagram post). The friend was navigating a complicated relationship situation and may not have fully grasped the emotional significance of the plans to OP.

While OP had good initial intentions and valid feelings of hurt, the response of badmouthing the friend to their entire group was disproportionate and harmful. The friend made a poor choice in how she handled the cancellation, but getting back together with a boyfriend and prioritizing that relationship on Valentine's Day, while hurtful, is understandable. OP's retaliation created more harm than the original offense. This is primarily about OP's reaction being worse than the friend's actions.

results.title: WIBTA if I didn’t want to spend Valentine’s Day with my girl

assessment_steps.analysis: OP appears to have genuine philosophical objections to Valentine's Day based on their Buddhist beliefs about materialism. They're not trying to hurt their girlfriend or avoid her out of malice. However, there's some question about whether prioritizing work over their relationship shows good faith effort to compromise or find alternative ways to show affection that align with their values.

The girlfriend would likely feel hurt, rejected, and unimportant if OP chooses work over spending time with her on a day she clearly values. This could damage their relationship and make her feel like OP doesn't care about her feelings or what matters to her. The harm is emotional but significant in a romantic relationship context.

While OP has sincere religious/philosophical reasons for disliking the holiday, completely dismissing their girlfriend's feelings and choosing work instead shows a lack of consideration for their partner. A compromise could involve spending time together without the material aspects OP objects to. The intent isn't malicious, but the approach lacks empathy and relationship skills.

The girlfriend may feel hurt, rejected, or unimportant if her boyfriend chooses work over spending Valentine's Day with her. This could damage their relationship and cause emotional pain. However, the harm is relatively minor - it's disappointment over one day, not a major betrayal or significant damage. The OP is also 16 and likely has legitimate work obligations.

The OP appears to have genuine philosophical objections to Valentine's Day based on his Buddhist beliefs about materialism. He's not trying to hurt his girlfriend maliciously - he has sincere religious/philosophical reasons for not wanting to participate. However, he seems somewhat dismissive of his girlfriend's feelings and desires, calling her approach 'over-the-top' when she's trying to express affection.

While the OP has legitimate beliefs about materialism, relationships require compromise and consideration of your partner's feelings. His girlfriend is trying to show affection in her way, and completely dismissing Valentine's Day without discussion or alternative suggestions shows a lack of consideration for her emotional needs. The harm to the relationship outweighs his philosophical stance on this particular issue.

results.title: AITA for telling the insurance company my sister scammed the

assessment_steps.analysis: OP's intent appears to be seeking justice and preventing insurance fraud. While there may be some anger and resentment about the sister's actions and being sole beneficiary of life insurance, the core motivation seems to be upholding legal and ethical standards. The sister's intent was likely desperation and poor judgment in an extremely traumatic moment - losing her father and then crashing his car while unlicensed. However, she chose to commit fraud rather than face consequences.

Multiple harms occurred: The sister committed insurance fraud, which harms the insurance company and other policyholders. She was driving without a license, endangering public safety. She involved her boyfriend in the fraud scheme. However, she was also in severe emotional distress having just watched her father die and was sleep-deprived. OP's reporting could result in serious legal consequences for the sister during an already traumatic time. The family relationships will likely be severely damaged.

While the sister was in an extremely vulnerable state having just lost her father, insurance fraud is a serious crime that cannot be excused by grief. OP has a legitimate concern about illegal activity and has a right to report it. The sister had alternatives (staying at uncle's house, letting boyfriend drive) but chose fraud instead. OP's action, while harsh timing-wise, serves to prevent a crime and uphold legal standards. The sister bears primary responsibility for her illegal choices.

Multiple parties were harmed: The insurance company faces financial fraud (~$50k+ car value), the sister committed insurance fraud which carries legal penalties, the family lost their father's car due to reckless driving without a license, and other family members were excluded from life insurance benefits. The sister also endangered public safety by driving without a license while exhausted after trauma. The harm is significant both financially and legally.

The sister's intent appears to be self-serving fraud - she deliberately lied to insurance, manipulated the beneficiary paperwork to exclude other family members from life insurance, and tried to cover up driving without a license. While grief may explain poor judgment in driving exhausted, it doesn't excuse the deliberate fraud attempts. OP's intent seems to be preventing fraud and seeking justice, though there may be some element of anger over being excluded from inheritance.

The sister committed multiple serious offenses: insurance fraud, driving without a license, and manipulating inheritance documents. While OP is reporting during a difficult family time, they are preventing ongoing fraud against an insurance company and upholding legal/ethical standards. The sister's grief doesn't justify deliberate fraud, and OP has a legitimate ethical obligation to report criminal activity.

results.title: AITA for not forgiving my friend?

assessment_steps.analysis: OP's initial joke appears to have been made in good faith without malicious intent - they were playfully joking about 'running away' which seems like typical friend banter. However, when the ex-partner apologized and took responsibility for their overreaction, OP's refusal to forgive and accusation of manipulation appears to be driven by defensiveness and possibly some lingering relationship tensions rather than genuine concern about being manipulated.

The ex-partner was genuinely hurt by the joke and reacted emotionally, but they recognized their overreaction, apologized, and took responsibility. OP's refusal to accept a sincere apology and accusation of manipulation likely caused additional emotional harm and escalated what could have been a resolved misunderstanding. The ex-partner's repetition of 'I ruined everything' after being told their apology wasn't accepted suggests they were further distressed by OP's response.

While the ex-partner initially overreacted to a harmless joke, they quickly recognized this, apologized sincerely, and took responsibility. OP's refusal to accept this apology and accusation of manipulation when someone was genuinely trying to make amends shows a lack of grace and emotional maturity. The ex-partner had already been reassured the party wasn't ruined, but OP's harsh response likely caused more harm than the original incident.

Multiple parties experienced emotional harm. The ex-partner was hurt by the 'running away' joke, causing them to sob and feel distressed at a social event. OP experienced harm from being yelled at and feeling blamed for not reading their ex's mind. The social atmosphere at the birthday party was disrupted. However, the harm was relatively minor - temporary emotional distress that was largely resolved when the ex calmed down and apologized, and the party continued successfully.

OP's initial joke appears to have been intended as harmless banter without malicious intent. The ex-partner's reaction (sobbing then yelling) seems driven by emotional sensitivity rather than deliberate harm. Their apology appears genuine as they acknowledged wrongdoing. However, OP's refusal to forgive and accusation of manipulation seems punitive rather than constructive. OP appears to be acting from hurt pride rather than seeking resolution.

While OP had legitimate grounds to be frustrated about being yelled at for not mind-reading, their response was disproportionately harsh. The ex-partner took responsibility, apologized genuinely, and the situation was resolved. OP's refusal to accept a sincere apology and accusation of manipulation appears vindictive and unnecessarily escalates conflict over what was essentially a miscommunication between friends.

results.title: AITA for calling my semi-friend a bitch?

assessment_steps.analysis: OP appears to be acting in response to sustained bullying and harassment from Emma. The intent seems to be self-defense and confrontation of harmful behavior rather than malicious aggression. OP explicitly states that rude comments were made 'in response to her actions' and sought an apology, suggesting good faith attempt to resolve the conflict. However, some retaliatory comments about Emma's appearance cross into bad faith territory.

Emma has caused significant harm through physical violence (kicking), social sabotage (destroying friendships, public humiliation about interests), verbal abuse, and emotional manipulation. OP has also caused harm through appearance-based insults, but this appears to be reactive and less systematic. Emma's actions seem more calculated to cause lasting social and emotional damage, while OP's actions appear more defensive in nature.

While OP did engage in name-calling and appearance-based insults which are wrong, this appears to be a clear case of a victim responding to sustained bullying and harassment. Emma's pattern of physical violence, social sabotage, public humiliation, and refusal to accept accountability when confronted demonstrates she is the primary aggressor. OP's actions, while not ideal, are understandable defensive responses to prolonged mistreatment.

Both parties caused significant harm. Emma caused physical harm (kicking), emotional harm (name-calling, social sabotage, destroying friendships), and reputational harm (broadcasting personal information, writing embarrassing things on school papers). OP caused emotional harm through retaliatory insults about Emma's appearance. Emma's harm appears more systematic, prolonged, and severe, including physical assault and deliberate social destruction. OP's harm was reactive and primarily verbal insults.

Emma's actions appear deliberately malicious - she admitted to hating OP, purposely destroyed friendships, and consistently engaged in bullying behavior. Her intent was clearly to cause harm and social isolation. OP's intent was defensive/retaliatory - responding to ongoing bullying and harassment. While OP's insults were mean, they were reactions to sustained abuse rather than unprovoked attacks. OP also attempted to apologize, showing some recognition of wrongdoing.

While OP's retaliatory insults were not ideal, they pale in comparison to Emma's systematic bullying campaign involving physical assault, social sabotage, and emotional abuse. Emma initiated the conflict, admitted to hatred, refused reconciliation, and showed no remorse. OP was defending themselves against a bully, though imperfectly. The harm Emma caused was far greater and her malicious intent clear.

results.title: AITA for caring more about my dog Fedor's death than about m

assessment_steps.analysis: OP appears to be experiencing intense grief and guilt over their dog's death. Their anger toward their father seems to stem from feeling that he's being self-centered by discussing his own health issues when OP wants focus on the dog. OP is processing complex emotions including self-blame, family frustration, and genuine love for their pet. The intent appears to be expressing grief rather than deliberately minimizing their father's serious health condition.

The harm here is primarily emotional and relational. OP's father is facing potentially life-threatening health issues (lung and heart problems), which are objectively serious medical emergencies. By prioritizing the dog's death over their father's health crisis, OP risks damaging family relationships and potentially missing critical moments with their father. However, OP is clearly in acute emotional distress and may not be thinking rationally. The dog's death also represents real loss and grief that shouldn't be dismissed.

While OP's grief over their beloved pet is completely valid and understandable, expecting family members to prioritize the dog's death over a father's serious health emergency crosses into problematic territory. Grief can cloud judgment, but the father's lung and potential heart failure represent immediate life-threatening conditions that warrant family concern and support. OP's emotional state is understandable, but their expectation that others should share their priorities in this situation is unreasonable.

The primary harm is the death of the dog Fedor, which appears to have been caused by neglect - the family noticed symptoms (inflated stomach, difficulty walking) for weeks but failed to seek veterinary care. OP also caused emotional harm to themselves through guilt and self-blame. The father in the hospital may have experienced emotional harm from OP's reaction prioritizing the dog's death over his health crisis. However, no direct harm was caused by OP's emotional priorities themselves - the dog's death was due to collective family neglect, not OP's grief response.

OP's intent appears to be genuine grief and love for their pet, not malicious disregard for their father. They acknowledge feeling guilty about potentially contributing to the dog's death and express frustration at the family's collective failure to seek medical care for the pet. Their anger toward the father seems rooted in feeling he's being self-centered during a moment of profound loss for OP. While the emotional response may seem disproportionate to others, OP is acting from a place of genuine attachment and grief, not intentional cruelty.

While OP's prioritization of their dog's death over their father's hospitalization may seem callous to others, they are processing genuine grief over a beloved pet's death that they feel partially responsible for. The real harm (dog's death) was caused by collective family neglect over weeks, not OP's emotional response. OP is not an asshole for grieving deeply or for feeling frustrated with family dynamics during a crisis - they're human and processing loss in their own way.

results.title: AITA for arguing with my wife and refusing to fire the nanny

assessment_steps.analysis: The husband's intent appears to be primarily practical - maintaining childcare stability while they find a replacement, and protecting what he sees as unfair treatment of an employee. However, he shows concerning disregard for his wife's emotional needs. The wife's intent seems mixed - she has legitimate discomfort about the nanny's past but chose manipulative tactics (involving the children) rather than direct communication. Her initial acceptance followed by change of heart suggests she tried to be mature but couldn't overcome her feelings.

Significant harm occurred to multiple parties: The children were emotionally manipulated and confused, told their caregiver was 'evil' which caused distress. The wife's feelings and boundaries were dismissed and she was called 'insecure and controlling.' The nanny, while unaware, is caught in a hostile situation. The marriage relationship suffered damage from the heated argument and lack of empathy. The wife's manipulation of the children was particularly harmful as it weaponized them in an adult conflict.

Both parties acted problematically. The wife manipulated the children and created an unnecessarily dramatic situation rather than communicating directly. The husband dismissed his wife's legitimate feelings, called her names, and prioritized practicality over his spouse's emotional wellbeing. While the husband has some valid points about finding proper solutions, his approach was dismissive and harmful. The wife's tactics were manipulative but stemmed from genuine discomfort she felt unable to express directly.

Multiple parties were harmed here. The children (ages 3, 6, 7) were psychologically manipulated by being told their caregiver is 'evil' and 'wants to hurt mommy,' causing the 6-year-old to cry and creating fear/distress. Sarah (the nanny) was professionally undermined and faced potential job loss due to decades-old high school drama unrelated to her work performance. The wife experienced emotional discomfort from the situation. The family unit suffered relationship strain from the heated argument. The children's harm is most concerning as they were used as pawns in an adult conflict and given false, frightening information about their caregiver.

The wife's intent was manipulative - she deliberately told the children false information about Sarah being 'evil' to weaponize them against the nanny, by her own admission hoping this would lead to Sarah's firing. This was calculated deception targeting vulnerable children. The husband's intent appears to be maintaining fairness and protecting both the family's childcare needs and Sarah's employment, though his approach became harsh when he called his wife 'insecure and controlling.' The wife was acting in bad faith by manipulating the children rather than addressing her discomfort directly through honest communication.

While the husband's delivery was harsh, his core position is ethically sound. The wife's manipulation of the children and attempt to destroy someone's livelihood over high school drama from decades ago is significantly more problematic. The husband is defending both the children's right to honest information and Sarah's right to fair treatment. The wife's actions caused direct psychological harm to the children and threatened Sarah's employment unfairly. Despite the husband's poor communication style in the argument, he is not the primary asshole here.

results.title: AITA for not letting my wife's brother stay at our place, wh

assessment_steps.analysis: The harm here is primarily to the brother-in-law who loses a temporary housing opportunity that could help him get back on his feet financially and secure employment. This could significantly impact his ability to improve his situation. The wife may also feel hurt by her husband's refusal to help her family member. However, there's potential harm to OP as well - risk of property damage, unwanted extended stay, or violation of personal space and belongings.

OP's intent appears to be protecting his property and personal comfort rather than maliciously harming the brother-in-law. His concerns about the brother's living habits and potential overstaying seem pragmatic rather than vindictive. However, his admission that he 'doesn't really like' the brother suggests some personal bias may be influencing his decision. The wife's intent is clearly to help her struggling family member.

While OP has legitimate concerns about his property and the risk of the arrangement becoming permanent, his decision is primarily based on personal dislike rather than objective risk assessment. The flat being 'his' before marriage doesn't negate his wife's stake in household decisions. The potential harm to the brother-in-law (losing housing opportunity) outweighs OP's discomfort, especially since they'll be away anyway. OP should have worked with his wife to establish clear boundaries rather than outright refusing.

OP's intent appears to be protecting their personal space and property based on legitimate concerns about the brother-in-law's lifestyle and potential overstaying. While they acknowledge it would help the brother, they prioritize their own comfort and property security. This seems like reasonable self-preservation rather than malicious intent, though there may be some personal dislike influencing the decision.

The harm is primarily to the brother-in-law who loses a temporary housing opportunity during financial hardship, and secondarily to the wife who may feel her family is being rejected. However, the potential harm to OP if the arrangement goes poorly (property damage, difficulty removing the brother, violation of personal space) is also significant. The harm is more about missed opportunity than active damage.

OP has legitimate property rights and reasonable concerns about allowing someone they don't trust to stay in their home unsupervised for a month. While it creates some family tension, OP is not obligated to take financial or property risks for extended family members, especially given their stated concerns about the brother's reliability and potential overstaying.

results.title: AITA for paying for my friend's dog to be cremated without a

assessment_steps.analysis: The primary harm is the breach of financial trust between spouses - the OP made a $200 financial decision without consulting their partner, which violates typical marital financial agreements. The husband experienced anger and felt his wishes were disregarded. The friend received help in a time of need. The financial impact was minimal given their stable finances. Overall harm is moderate due to the trust violation but mitigated by the small amount and good outcome for the grieving friend.

The OP acted with compassionate intent, responding to a friend's emotional crisis and the death of a beloved pet. They were motivated by genuine grief and desire to help someone in distress. However, they knowingly chose to circumvent their husband's likely objection, showing they understood this would cause conflict. The intent was good-faith help for someone suffering, though executed in a way that avoided marital discussion.

While the OP's compassionate response to a friend's crisis shows good intent, making unilateral financial decisions in a marriage - even small ones - represents a breach of typical spousal consultation norms. The harm to marital trust outweighs the emergency nature of the situation, especially since the OP could have discussed it with their husband first or immediately after. The good intentions don't fully excuse the poor execution.

OP acted with compassionate intent, wanting to help a grieving friend during an emotional crisis involving a beloved pet's death. However, OP deliberately chose not to discuss this with their husband beforehand, knowing he would disapprove. While the core motivation was empathetic and altruistic, the decision to act unilaterally in a marriage shows some disregard for partnership dynamics.

The financial harm is minimal ($200 from a household that's not struggling). The primary harm is to the marriage relationship through breach of trust and unilateral financial decision-making. The husband feels his concerns about the friend being 'too needy' were dismissed. However, the friend received significant help during a genuine crisis, and no one suffered major material damage.

While OP's compassionate response to a friend's crisis was admirable, making unilateral financial decisions in marriage, even for good reasons, violates partnership principles. The deliberate choice to act without discussion, knowing the spouse would object, constitutes a breach of trust. However, the circumstances were extenuating (emergency, beloved pet's death, minimal amount), making this a borderline case where OP's heart was in the right place but execution was problematic.

results.title: AITA for reading my brother's journal??

assessment_steps.analysis: Significant harm occurred on multiple levels. The brother experienced a severe violation of privacy and trust - his journal was described as 'the only valued thing he's got,' indicating it was his safe space for processing trauma and mental health struggles. The breach revealed deeply personal content including suicidal ideation and childhood trauma. This violation likely damaged their relationship (he hasn't spoken to OP since) and potentially set back his mental health progress by destroying his primary coping mechanism and safe outlet.

OP's intentions appear to be genuinely caring - she was concerned about her brother's mental health changes and isolation. She states she wanted to help him feel 'loved not abandoned' and had previously tried to get him to open up through direct communication. However, the method chosen (reading private journal) was a clear violation of boundaries, even if motivated by concern. Good intentions don't justify harmful actions, especially when dealing with someone's private mental health struggles.

While OP had caring intentions, the harm caused significantly outweighs the good intentions. Reading someone's private journal, especially someone struggling with mental health and suicidal thoughts, is a serious violation of trust and privacy. The brother's reaction shows the deep damage done. OP should have sought help from parents, school counselors, or mental health professionals rather than violating his privacy. Good intentions don't excuse harmful boundary violations.

OP's intentions appear to be genuinely caring and concern-driven. She noticed significant behavioral changes in her brother (isolation, emotional withdrawal, physical signs of stress like premature white hair) and was worried about his mental health. Her goal was to understand what was wrong and help him feel loved and valued. However, her method of trying to help - violating his privacy by reading his journal - was misguided even if well-intentioned.

The harm caused is significant and multifaceted. OP violated her brother's privacy by reading his most personal thoughts, including deeply painful experiences like feeling unloved and having suicidal ideation. The brother explicitly stated the journal was 'the only valued thing he's got,' indicating it was his sole safe space for processing trauma. By reading it, OP destroyed that sanctuary and likely deepened his feelings of having no privacy or safety. The brother's angry reaction and subsequent silence suggests substantial emotional harm and further isolation.

While OP's intentions were caring, the violation of privacy was a serious breach of trust that caused real harm to someone already struggling with mental health issues. Good intentions don't excuse harmful actions, especially when they involve reading someone's private journal containing suicidal thoughts. The brother's strong negative reaction demonstrates the severity of the violation. OP should have sought other ways to help, such as involving parents or mental health professionals.

results.title: AITAH for not being there for my friend

assessment_steps.analysis: OP's intentions are mixed but not malicious. They are making some effort to be supportive (checking in, responding to messages) but struggling internally due to past hurt. Their reluctance stems from feeling abandoned during their own crisis, not from wanting to deliberately harm their friend. They show self-awareness about their conflicted feelings and question whether they're doing enough, indicating they want to do right but are emotionally constrained by past experience.

The harm is relatively limited. OP is still providing some support (checking in, being available for updates) but not as much as they could. The friend may feel some lack of support during a difficult time, but OP hasn't completely abandoned them. The greater harm occurred previously when the friend abandoned OP during their bereavement, creating lasting emotional damage that affects OP's ability to be fully present now.

While OP could ideally rise above past hurts to provide fuller support, they are still making genuine efforts despite their emotional struggles. The friend's previous abandonment of OP during grief was more severe than OP's current limited availability. OP is not acting out of malice but processing legitimate hurt while still trying to be supportive. Their self-reflection and continued effort, even while struggling, shows they are not being an asshole.

The friend is experiencing emotional harm from receiving reduced support during a difficult time when a relative is dying. However, OP is still providing some support by checking in, just not as much as they could. The harm is moderate - the friend isn't completely abandoned but isn't getting full emotional support. In comparison, when OP lost a family member, the friend completely ignored them for 3 weeks, causing significant emotional harm during grief.

OP's intent appears conflicted but not malicious. They genuinely want to do the right thing and feel guilty about not being more supportive. They're struggling with unresolved hurt from their friend's past behavior, but they're still making an effort to be there. The friend's original intent when OP was grieving was self-preservation (avoiding 'negativity'), which while understandable, was insensitive and abandoning during OP's time of need.

While OP could be more supportive, they're still providing some support despite their hurt feelings. The friend previously completely abandoned OP during grief, which was more harmful. OP is wrestling with natural human emotions about reciprocity while still trying to do right by their friend. Their reduced but present support doesn't make them an asshole, especially given the context of how they were treated.

results.title: AITA for getting too drunk (as an alcoholic) at a party wher

assessment_steps.analysis: Multiple parties were harmed here. OP experienced harm by relapsing from their sobriety and compromising their recovery as an alcoholic. The friends experienced some disruption from OP's intoxicated behavior, though OP notes it wasn't serious. The most significant harm was to OP's health and sobriety, which can have lasting consequences for someone with alcohol addiction.

OP's intent was initially good - they recognized their problem and attempted to avoid drinking by stating this upfront. They tried to resist peer pressure but eventually gave in. The friends acted in bad faith by pressuring someone they knew had an alcohol problem to drink, showing disregard for OP's wellbeing and recovery. OP's relapse wasn't intentional malice but rather succumbing to pressure while struggling with addiction.

While OP bears some responsibility for ultimately choosing to drink, the primary fault lies with the friends who knowingly pressured someone with alcohol addiction to drink. OP made an effort to avoid the situation initially and tried to resist. The friends' behavior was particularly egregious given their knowledge of OP's condition. This is primarily the friends' fault for creating a harmful situation.

OP initially acted in good faith by clearly communicating their alcoholism and desire not to drink. When pressured by friends who knew about their condition, OP tried to resist but eventually gave in. The friends acted in bad faith by knowingly pressuring someone with a drinking problem to consume alcohol despite explicit refusal. OP's eventual drinking appears to be the result of compromised judgment under peer pressure rather than malicious intent.

OP acknowledges causing 'a problem' but describes it as 'not serious.' The harm appears relatively minor in scope. However, the friends caused significant harm by pressuring someone with alcoholism to drink, potentially triggering relapse and undermining recovery efforts. The friends' behavior was particularly harmful given their knowledge of OP's condition and explicit refusal to drink.

While OP bears some responsibility for ultimately choosing to drink, the friends' behavior was significantly worse. They knowingly pressured someone with alcoholism to consume alcohol despite clear refusal, exploiting a vulnerable situation. OP was trying to maintain sobriety and explicitly communicated boundaries that the friends violated. The friends created the harmful situation through peer pressure against someone in recovery.

results.title: AITA for arguing with my parents for waking me up in their h

assessment_steps.analysis: OP appears to be acting in good faith, seeking basic rest and self-care during a rare opportunity when his daughter is away. His frustration stems from exhaustion and lack of personal time. The parents seem to have mixed intentions - they have legitimate home improvement needs but appear inflexible and inconsiderate of OP's circumstances, despite knowing about his misophonia and demanding schedule.

OP is experiencing sleep deprivation, stress, and inability to practice self-care, which could impact his ability to parent and work effectively. The parents are experiencing minor inconvenience of scheduling around OP's needs. However, OP is living in their house rent-free (implied) and they are providing childcare support. The harm to OP appears more significant given his already stressful situation as a young single parent.

While the parents own the house and have the right to renovate, their lack of consideration for OP's rare opportunity for rest, combined with their apparent flexibility in work schedules, makes them inconsiderate. OP's frustration is understandable given his circumstances, though his approach could have been more diplomatic. The parents' response of 'sleep somewhere else' shows lack of empathy for their son's situation.

The primary harm is to OP's physical and mental wellbeing - sleep deprivation, no recovery time, and exposure to triggering noises due to misophonia during his only opportunity for rest. The parents experience minor inconvenience of scheduling work differently. OP works exhaustively as a young single father with no support system, making this harm particularly severe given his circumstances. The timing specifically denies him his only chance for self-care in what appears to be months.

The parents appear to be acting primarily out of convenience rather than malice - they want to complete home renovations while the baby isn't present to avoid disturbing her. However, they show little consideration for OP's desperate need for rest and recovery. OP's reaction comes from exhaustion and frustration at being denied his only opportunity for self-care. While the parents have legitimate property rights, their dismissive attitude ('sleep somewhere else') suggests they're not acting in good faith toward their son's wellbeing.

While the parents have the legal right to renovate their house, their timing shows a lack of empathy for their exhausted son who works constantly to support his child. They have flexible schedules but choose to work during OP's only rest opportunity, despite knowing about his misophonia. OP's argument, while emotional, is reasonable given his extreme circumstances. The harm to OP's wellbeing outweighs the parents' convenience, especially since they have other options for scheduling.

results.title: AITA for leaving pee in the toilet

assessment_steps.analysis: The OP appears to be acting in good faith. They explicitly state they want to be better and show embarrassment about the behavior. The forgetting appears to be genuinely unintentional, occurring only once or twice monthly and potentially linked to their ADHD, which can affect memory and attention to routine tasks. There's no indication of malicious intent or deliberate inconsideration.

The harm is relatively minor - occasional unflushed urine that the partner discovers and comments on. While this creates some inconvenience and hygiene concerns for the partner, the frequency is low (1-2 times per month) and the OP shows awareness and remorse. The partner's consistent comments suggest mild frustration but no indication of severe relationship damage or health risks.

Given the good faith intent, genuine efforts to improve, low frequency of occurrence, minor nature of the harm, and the potential connection to a medical condition (ADHD), this appears to be an unfortunate but understandable human mistake rather than asshole behavior. The OP is clearly trying to be considerate and is embarrassed by their lapses.

The harm is relatively minor - the fiancé encounters unflushed urine once or twice monthly, which is unpleasant and unhygienic but causes no lasting damage. This creates a minor inconvenience and potentially some disgust/frustration for the partner. No significant physical, emotional, or relationship harm has occurred based on the description.

The OP's intent is clearly not malicious - they acknowledge embarrassment about the behavior, express desire to improve, and recognize it as a problem. The forgetting appears genuinely linked to ADHD symptoms rather than carelessness or disrespect. They show good faith by seeking advice and demonstrating concern about the impact on their relationship.

Given the minimal harm (minor inconvenience), genuine lack of malicious intent, and OP's acknowledgment of the issue with desire to improve, this appears to be an innocent mistake related to a medical condition rather than asshole behavior. The fiancé's comments seem reasonable given the recurring nature, but OP is not acting wrongly.

results.title: AITA for not wanting to hang out after surgery?

The girlfriend's passive-aggressive response suggests some disappointment but doesn't indicate malicious intent, just poor communication of her feelings.

OP acted reasonably by declining social activities while recovering from surgery and caring for his children. He communicated honestly and respectfully about his limitations. Taking care of one's health and children after medical procedures is appropriate self-care, not selfish behavior. The girlfriend's disappointment is understandable but her passive-aggressive response was unnecessary.

OP's intent appears to be honest self-care and responsible parenting. He clearly communicated his physical limitations after surgery and his struggle to manage basic responsibilities with his children. His response was direct but polite, explaining both his desire to spend time with his girlfriend and his current inability to do so. There's no indication of bad faith - he's being transparent about his condition and limitations.

The harm here is minimal. The girlfriend experienced disappointment from having her invitation declined, which resulted in a somewhat passive-aggressive response. However, OP is recovering from surgery, caring for three children alone, and managing pain without medication. His prioritization of recovery and childcare responsibilities over social activities is reasonable and necessary. The girlfriend's curt response suggests some hurt feelings, but this is a minor interpersonal disappointment rather than significant harm.

OP acted reasonably by honestly communicating his limitations after surgery. He's managing pain, recovery, and single parenting responsibilities. His girlfriend's passive-aggressive response to a legitimate health-related decline shows less understanding than expected from a partner. OP is not wrong for prioritizing his recovery and children's needs over socializing while in pain.

results.title: AITA for suggesting to my friend we don't use TikTok in our

However, they're not being malicious and are trying to resolve the disagreement professionally. The friend also has valid points about TikTok's marketing reach. This appears to be a legitimate business disagreement between partners with different priorities rather than asshole behavior from either party.

The harm here is minimal. The OP suggested alternative social media platforms based on privacy concerns, which temporarily created disagreement with their business partner. No actual damage occurred - no business was lost, no relationships were permanently damaged, and no one was hurt. The friend was simply surprised by the suggestion but remained engaged in finding a solution. The conflict appears to be a normal business disagreement that they're working to resolve constructively.

The OP's intentions appear to be genuinely good faith. They expressed legitimate privacy concerns about TikTok and suggested alternatives they believed would be better for data protection. They proposed doing thorough analysis to resolve the conflict and even offered to bring in a knowledgeable friend to provide free expert advice. The OP seems motivated by wanting to protect both their business and their customers' privacy, not by any desire to control or undermine their partner.

Given the minimal harm (just a temporary disagreement) and the OP's good faith intentions to protect privacy and find the best solution for their venture, the OP is not the asshole. They approached the disagreement constructively by suggesting further research and expert consultation rather than being dismissive or controlling.

results.title: AITA for "parking like an asshole"

assessment_steps.analysis: The primary harm is inconvenience and escalation of conflict. The neighbors are harmed by having difficulty accessing their vehicle when OP parks close to the line. OP was harmed by having their Jeep keyed (though they claim not to care much). The parking violations resulted in fines for the neighbors. However, the harm is relatively minor - mostly inconvenience rather than significant damage or safety issues. The keying represents the most serious escalation but OP handled it with minimal concern.

OP's intent appears to be enforcing proper parking etiquette rather than malicious harassment. They state they park centered when arriving first, only park close when neighbors park over the line, and never actually damage the neighbor's vehicle. OP seems motivated by principle (making neighbors 'park like adults') rather than spite. However, there's some pettiness in the approach and OP admits they wouldn't behave this way with a nicer car, suggesting some opportunistic antagonism.

While OP's methods are somewhat petty and confrontational, they are fundamentally responding to the neighbors' parking violations rather than initiating the problem. The neighbors consistently park over the line, forcing OP to either accommodate their poor parking or respond assertively. OP's response is proportionate - they don't damage property and they follow proper channels by reporting violations. The neighbors escalated by yelling and potentially keying the Jeep. OP is enforcing reasonable parking standards.

OP's intent appears mixed. Initially, they seem motivated by fairness - wanting neighbors to park properly within their assigned spots rather than encroaching over the line. However, there's also a retaliatory element and some enjoyment of the conflict ('I laughed', calling neighbors 'knuckle dragging troglodytes'). The intent shifts from reasonable boundary-setting to somewhat antagonistic behavior, though OP maintains they're enforcing proper parking etiquette.

The harm is relatively minor but escalating. OP's parking forces neighbors to inconvenience themselves (crawling in, adjusting mirrors) but doesn't cause property damage. The neighbors were fined by the condo board for parking violations. Someone (possibly the neighbors) keyed OP's Jeep, indicating escalation. The main harm is the ongoing conflict and tension in the community, plus the practical inconvenience to both parties.

While OP has a legitimate right to park properly in their assigned spot and enforce parking rules, their approach has become unnecessarily antagonistic. The neighbors are clearly wrong for parking over the line, but OP is escalating the situation beyond what's necessary. OP could have simply reported the parking violations without the passive-aggressive close parking. Both parties are behaving poorly - neighbors by parking improperly and OP by deliberately antagonizing rather than seeking constructive solutions.

results.title: AITA for accidentally blowing smoke into someone's face?

assessment_steps.analysis: The harm was moderate. OP blew smoke directly into someone's face who has a respiratory condition, which could cause immediate discomfort, breathing difficulties, or potentially trigger health issues. The person was harmed physically (respiratory exposure) and the situation escalated into a verbal confrontation that required security intervention. The harm was compounded by OP's aggressive response when confronted.

OP's initial action was unintentional - they were smoking with eyes closed and didn't realize someone was there. However, after being informed the person had a respiratory condition and being called a name, OP chose to escalate rather than de-escalate. The initial smoking violation was due to being 'brain fried' rather than malicious intent, but the hostile response showed poor judgment and lack of empathy for someone with health concerns.

While the initial smoke incident was accidental, OP bears responsibility for smoking in a prohibited area and for escalating the confrontation after learning about the person's respiratory condition. The other person's harsh language was understandable given their health concern and the direct impact on them. OP should have been more apologetic and understanding rather than telling them to 'piss off.'

The OP's initial action of smoking near the building doors was careless but not malicious - they admit their brain was 'fried' and they didn't notice the rule violation. The actual smoke-blowing was completely accidental with eyes closed. However, after the other person explained they had a respiratory condition, OP escalated by telling them to 'piss off' rather than showing empathy or continuing to apologize. This shift from accidental harm to intentional hostility is problematic.

The harm was significant - OP blew smoke directly into the face of someone with a respiratory condition, which could cause serious health consequences. While the initial smoke exposure was accidental, OP's hostile response after learning about the person's medical condition added emotional harm and showed disregard for the physical harm already caused. The person's strong reaction ('dumbfuck') was likely due to genuine health concern and fear.

While the initial smoke incident was truly accidental, OP becomes the asshole through their response afterward. When someone with a respiratory condition explained the serious impact, the appropriate response would be sincere apology and concern for their wellbeing. Instead, OP got defensive, told them to 'piss off,' and escalated the conflict. The combination of rule-breaking (smoking in non-smoking zone), causing harm to someone with a medical condition, and then responding with hostility makes OP the asshole.

results.title: AITA for not taking new orders for my fiance's baking busine

assessment_steps.analysis: The harm here is relatively minor. The coworkers who inquired about orders may be slightly inconvenienced by not being able to place orders, but this is minimal harm. The fiancé might miss out on some business income, but given her current mental health crisis and medication adjustments, taking on additional work stress could cause significant harm to her wellbeing and ability to care for the children. The protection of her mental health and family stability outweighs the minor business opportunity loss.

The OP's intentions appear to be entirely protective and caring. He is responding to a serious mental health situation where his fiancé has been diagnosed with manic depression and bipolar 2, is on new heavy medication, and needs supervision while caring for young children. His decision to decline new orders on her behalf stems from genuine concern for her wellbeing and recognition that additional work stress could be detrimental during this vulnerable time. There's no indication of malicious intent or attempt to control her business negatively.

Given that the OP acted to protect his fiancé's mental health during a critical period when she's adjusting to serious psychiatric medication and managing postpartum depression with two very young children, his actions were reasonable and caring. The minimal harm of missed business opportunities is far outweighed by the potential serious harm that additional work stress could cause to someone in a fragile mental state. His protective intentions were appropriate given the medical advice they received.

The OP's intention appears to be protective and caring. He is concerned about his fiancé's mental health (postpartum depression, manic depression, bipolar 2), her current stress levels with two young children, and her recent prescription of heavy medication that requires adult supervision. He declined new orders to protect her wellbeing during a vulnerable time, not out of malice or control, but from genuine concern for her safety and capacity.

The primary harm is that the fiancé lost potential business income and wasn't consulted about her own business decisions. However, this must be weighed against the potential harm of overloading someone with serious mental health issues who is on new medication requiring supervision. The medical advice explicitly stated she needed another adult present due to medication effects on her ability to care for children. Additional work stress could exacerbate her mental health condition.

While the OP should have consulted his fiancé first, his intentions were clearly protective given her serious mental health diagnosis and medical requirements. The potential harm from taking on more work during this critical period likely outweighs the harm from declining orders. His decision was made from a place of care and concern for her wellbeing during a medically vulnerable time.

results.title: AITA for being reluctant at letting my girlfriend's brother

assessment_steps.analysis: The harm here is relatively minor but emotionally significant. The girlfriend faces the difficult position of trying to accommodate both her long-distance boyfriend and brother whom she rarely sees due to visa restrictions. The brother appears unharmed as he gets to visit his sister. Overall harm is low-level interpersonal conflict with some emotional distress but no severe consequences.

OP's intentions appear to be wanting quality time with his girlfriend after a long separation and feeling prioritized in the relationship. His reluctance seems driven by genuine emotional needs rather than malice. The girlfriend's intentions appear to be trying to balance competing demands - wanting to see her brother (uncertain future visits due to visa issues) while also spending time with OP. She's constrained by Airbnb occupancy rules she's trying to respect. Both parties seem to be acting in good faith with understandable motivations, though perhaps lacking in communication and compromise.

This is a case where both parties have legitimate needs and concerns but are struggling to find a mutually acceptable solution. OP isn't wrong for wanting time with his girlfriend after months apart, and the girlfriend isn't wrong for wanting to see her brother given visa uncertainties. The girlfriend could have been more collaborative in finding solutions, and OP could be more understanding of the difficult position she's in. This appears to be a relationship conflict where both parties need better communication rather than either being definitively in the wrong.

OP's intent appears to be wanting to spend quality time with his girlfriend during their rare in-person visit after months apart. His reluctance stems from feeling deprioritized and wanting to be included rather than excluded. The girlfriend's intent seems to be accommodating her brother whom she rarely sees due to visa restrictions, while trying to follow Airbnb occupancy rules. Both parties appear to be acting in good faith with understandable motivations - OP wanting couple time and girlfriend wanting family time.

The harm is relatively minor but emotional. OP feels hurt and deprioritized, creating tension in their relationship. The girlfriend is caught between two important relationships and feels frustrated that OP doesn't understand her difficult position. The brother would potentially be harmed if not accommodated, as this may be a rare opportunity to see his sister. The relationship tension from poor communication is the primary damage, but no severe or lasting harm appears to have occurred.

Both parties have legitimate needs and concerns. OP's desire to spend time with his girlfriend after months apart is reasonable, as is his feeling of being excluded. However, the girlfriend also has valid reasons for wanting to see her brother whom she rarely gets to visit due to visa constraints. Neither party is acting maliciously - this is a scheduling conflict with competing priorities. The girlfriend could have communicated better about finding alternative solutions, but OP could also be more understanding of the rare family visit opportunity.

results.title: AITA for Not Thanking my MIL for Chicken?

assessment_steps.analysis: The immediate harm is relatively minor - unwanted food that creates waste and storage issues. However, the pattern of behavior described suggests ongoing emotional harm through boundary violations, passive-aggressive behavior, and manipulative tactics. The MIL's actions demonstrate a disregard for clearly expressed needs (OP said they had too much chicken) and create marital conflict. The husband's pressure for gratitude compounds the harm by invalidating OP's legitimate concerns about boundary violations.

The MIL's intent appears problematic given the context. She was explicitly told multiple times that OP already had too much chicken and acknowledged understanding this, yet still brought more chicken the next day. Combined with the pattern of manipulative behaviors described (fake illnesses, inappropriate comments, boundary violations), this suggests deliberate passive-aggressive behavior rather than genuine helpfulness. The timing and nature of the 'gift' indicates intent to create obligation, guilt, or conflict rather than genuine care.

OP is not the asshole for refusing to thank MIL for unwanted chicken that directly contradicted their explicitly stated needs. The MIL's action appears to be part of a pattern of boundary violations and manipulative behavior. While the husband may genuinely believe his mother meant well, OP's refusal to participate in validating boundary-crossing behavior is reasonable and appropriate. The broader context of MIL's problematic behaviors supports OP's assessment that this was not a genuine act of kindness.

The OP's intent appears to be good faith - they were trying to make conversation with a difficult MIL by discussing cooking. However, the MIL's intent seems questionable given the context. Despite the OP explicitly stating multiple times they were overwhelmed by too much chicken, the MIL delivered even more chicken the next day. Combined with the pattern of manipulative behavior described (weight comments, fake illnesses, inappropriate gifts, etc.), this appears to be passive-aggressive behavior designed to create obligation and drama rather than genuine helpfulness.

The harm here is primarily emotional and relational. The OP was forced into an uncomfortable position where refusing to thank someone for an unwanted 'gift' makes them appear ungrateful, while thanking them enables manipulative behavior. This created conflict with their husband and added stress to an already difficult relationship. The MIL's action also wasted food and ignored clearly stated boundaries. While the immediate harm is relatively minor, it's part of a larger pattern of boundary violations that cause ongoing emotional distress.

The OP is not the asshole. They clearly communicated they had too much chicken and were overwhelmed, yet the MIL ignored this and delivered more chicken anyway. Given the documented pattern of manipulative behavior, this appears to be a deliberate boundary violation designed to create obligation and conflict. The OP has no obligation to thank someone for an unwanted 'gift' that ignores their clearly stated needs, especially when it appears to be part of ongoing manipulative behavior.

results.title: AITA for telling my sibling to “call home in case of emergen

assessment_steps.analysis: The harm here is relatively minor - emotional hurt and miscommunication between siblings. The sibling felt dismissed or brushed off by OP's message, interpreting it as 'don't bother me.' OP felt hurt by the sibling's defensive response. OP's intent appears to have been genuinely helpful - they were passing along their mother's instruction about calling the house for emergencies since OP would be unreachable with phone off. OP was acting in good faith, trying to provide emergency contact information. The sibling seems to have misinterpreted this as dismissive, but OP clarified their meaning when they realized the misunderstanding. Both parties appear to have been acting without malicious intent.

This is a classic case of miscommunication where neither party intended harm. OP was trying to be helpful by sharing emergency contact info, while the sibling misunderstood the tone. OP took responsibility by clarifying their meaning when they realized the miscommunication. No one acted with malicious intent or unreasonable behavior.

OP's intent appears to be genuinely helpful - they were following their mother's instruction to inform family members to call the house for emergencies since OP would be unavailable. The voice note was meant to provide practical information for emergency contact, not to be dismissive. OP was acting in good faith by relaying their mother's emergency contact preferences.

The harm was primarily miscommunication-based. The sibling felt dismissed and interpreted the message as 'don't bother me,' leading to hurt feelings and defensive responses. However, the harm was relatively minor - hurt feelings from a misunderstood text message. No significant or lasting damage occurred, just temporary interpersonal tension that could be resolved with clarification.

This appears to be a case of miscommunication rather than intentional wrongdoing. OP had good intentions in relaying emergency contact information as instructed by their mother. The sibling's reaction, while understandable given the potential for misinterpretation in text communication, was somewhat defensive. Since OP acted with good faith intentions and attempted to clarify the misunderstanding, they are not the asshole in this situation.

results.title: AITA for telling my husband we can't buy a new laptop until
